text: Urbanized areas in the United States are defined by the U.S. Census Bureau as contiguous census block groups with a population density of at least 1,000 per square mile (about 400 per square km). Urban areas are delineated without regard to political boundaries. Urban areas with a population of at least 50,000 serve as the core of a metropolitan statistical area.Census 2010 Urban and Rural Classification. United States Census Bureau. Accessed October 16, 2016. ==Areas over 100,000== The following is a list of urbanized areas in the American Midwest with a population of at least 100,000. States within the Midwest are Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota and Wisconsin. Areas are ranked based on population as listed in the 2010 U.S. Census. {|class="wikitable" | style="text-align:right;" |- style="text-align:center;" !Rank !Urbanized Area !Population (2010 census)Alphabetically sorted list of Urbanized Areas.
